Context:
The Behavioural Science Technician program at the college includes studies in behavioural theory and application, program development, scientific method, ethics and professionalism, diversity, and general education with a practical emphasis. Students may be required to travel for field education placements within the Greater Toronto Area (GTA), which could last up to seven weeks each in semesters 3 and 4. The Association for Behaviour Analysis International has verified certain courses in this program toward the requirements for taking the Board Certified Assistant Behaviour Analyst® examination.

This program offers two intensive field placements, with students expected to spend approximately 7.5 hours per day, four days a week off-site and one day on-site at George Brown College. Placements will be conducted with clients who may have autism, mental health issues, acquired brain injury, developmental disabilities, behavioural concerns or issues related to aging. Partner agencies are located across the GTA.

Graduates of this program may find employment in various settings including ABA therapy programs, schools, hospitals, residential and treatment facilities, and vocational agencies, among others. Required courses for the Behavioural Science Technician program during semester 2 include BST 1003 - Behavioural Theory.
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2024/Behavioural Science Technician Program (Accelerated) C156 | George Brown College2024.txt

Context:
The text provides information about the courses offered in Semesters 3 and 4 of a Behavioural Theory and Practice program at the college. Here is the extracted information:

Semester 3:
- Codes: BST 2036, BST 2037, BST 2041, BST 2044, BST 2027, BST 2038, BST 2042, BST 2043
- Course names: Behaviour Theory and Practice: Acquisition Strategies, Behaviour Theory and Practice: Reduction Strategies, Behaviour Theory and Practice: Group-Based Interventions, ABA Application to Special Populations, Field Seminar II, Field Placement II

Semester 4:
- Codes: BST 2042, BST 2043
- Course names: Field Seminar III, Field Placement III

Program Learning Outcomes:
- Implement effective behaviour analytic intervention strategies based on the science of Applied Behaviour Analysis (ABA)
- Integrate background information and knowledge of special populations into therapeutic practice
- Communicate behaviour analytic principles, processes and concepts to various stakeholders
- Compile measurements of behaviour in accordance with ONTABA standards and BACB guidelines
- Apply systems thinking to behavioural processes related to socially significant behaviour change
- Adhere to federal, provincial and professional policies and regulations associated with ethical practice of ABA
- Apply input gained from collaboration with stakeholders and professionals into effective client service intervention
- Develop reflective practice using professional development and self-care strategies
- Develop client-centred behavioural intervention plans
- Integrate conceptual and philosophical underpinnings of behaviour analysis into comprehensive case formulation of human behaviour.

Tuition & Fees (not mentioned in the text).

Context:
* Students are required to submit certain documents by program-specific deadlines to ParaMed Placement Pass website for titres, Two-Step TB Skin Test, and Vulnerable Sector Check.
* Public Health recommends that students working with young children and other vulnerable communities be fully vaccinated against COVID-19. Students who are not fully vaccinated may not be able to complete field placement in the regularly scheduled time frame.
* Students who do not comply with program’s health policy and non-academic requirements or who do not submit all required documentation by deadlines will be excluded from clinical practicum.
* All costs, service fees, and fines associated with health requirements are the responsibility of students.
* Students in this program are required to have a Vulnerable Sector Check completed and renewed every year before entering into field or clinical placement.
* The Vulnerable Sector Check process typically takes 2-3 months but can take up to 4-8 months.
* Students are responsible for ensuring that the Vulnerable Sector Check covers appropriateness for individuals working with vulnerable persons.
* Students who cannot provide a "clear" Vulnerable Sector Check may not be able to start their field or clinical placement and may jeopardize their progress in the program.
* Failure to meet requirements for field placement can prevent students from completing the program and securing employment.
* Fees for the vulnerable sector check vary.
